body.p:
Thanking you for your treating the
subject in which I am the foremost actor or
rather sufferer with your usual boldness; I
hasten to give you the outlines of the continua„
tion of the Spanier comedy.

When L. Spanier saw, that his very pious
question in the papers brought no satisfactory
answer before the people; he tried the force of
money. He paid the dues for those, that could not
pay themselves; he gave money and promised the
more to every body, who came to him and so he
bought so many votes, that his party increased to
45 or 49. He then called a meeting at a time
when never a meeting was, when many members
were absent, and others had not time to attend; He
did not as usually say what business will be
transacted at that meeting, so that were altogether
indifferent to the whole concern. But when the
meeting was organized he brought the very charges
against me before that meeting with which he
failed at the meeting of the Board. My friends
protested against the reading of such charges; but in
vain. They proposed to adjourn the meeting; but
in vain; he put no motion before the meeting.
Finally the majority of the Board declared the meeting
adjourned and withdrew together with all my
friends. But Spanier with his party continued
the meeting, and resolved that the contract
between me and them is dissolved and
that I am discharged from my office from
that very day, September 5.
The majority of the Board declared that meeting

illegal and ordered me to discharge my duties as
ever before, my counsellor advised me the same.
The first day of Hebrew when I went up to Hebrew
Hebrew L. Spanier went to the Hebrew and
not merely pushed me, but in a rage of madness
stroke me several times. Hundreds commenced
at once to hollar: Throw him out the
bankrupt, the run of from Germany, all young
men in the Synagogue run against him, and
would have paid him, when suddenly the
Sherif came and dissolved the meeting and
locked up the Synagogue. Legal investigation
will be held in the matter. My friends 75 to
80 have seperated from the congregation, since
I have declared to enter no more this Synagogue
A new Congregation will be constituted and a
new Synagogue built. We rented a hall for
the purpose to worship in it, which was
always thus overfilled, that many could not
come in. The members of the Congregation
subscribed in one evening $1500.00 for a new
Synagogue; so if we helped a little we will have
soon a new building. The choir went with
us, and so we have our divine service just
exactly as before. The first day of Hebrew the
old Synagogue was reopened, when L. Spanier came with
his 45 (others having not made up their mind went to
no Synagogue) and held divine service. A
mournful sadness prevails here as I never
saw before. A congregation was destroyed
by the ill-will, pride, egotism and folly
of L. Spanier, which none can re-unite Hebrew
We had a Hebrew and a Hebrew as I never have
lived to see before Hebrew
I will write you every news, when something
shall transpire.

If your weekly paper appear you can sent
to us a dozen of copies, for which subscribers
are here, who gave up the Asmonean.
I am to much confused to answer Mr.
Miller's letter; but I will surely answer him one
day for his imprudent and improper introduction
your articles on Hebrew and Hebrew I shall closely
examine, and I will take the liberty to write down
my opposite opinion.

You must excuse me for the present
I am not disposed to write any thing reasonable?
